skos.definition: A syndrome of skeletal muscle injury with release of intracellular contents (myoglobin, creatine kinase, potassium, phosphate) into the circulation, often causing acute kidney injury through myoglobin-induced tubular toxicity.
skos.scopeNote: Common cause of AKI; 7-10% of all AKI cases; prognosis good with early aggressive treatment

content.title: Rhabdomyolysis and Myoglobinuric Acute Kidney Injury
content.summary: Rhabdomyolysis is skeletal muscle breakdown releasing myoglobin, creatine kinase, and other intracellular contents. Myoglobin is nephrotoxic, causing AKI through tubular obstruction, direct tubular toxicity, and renal vasoconstriction. Early recognition and aggressive fluid resuscitation are critical for prevention of AKI and other complications.
key_points: Creatine kinase (CK) >5× ULN (typically >10,000 U/L) is diagnostic
Myoglobin causes AKI through obstruction, direct toxicity, and vasoconstriction
Dark brown urine (cola-colored) with positive blood on dipstick but few RBCs on microscopy
Life-threatening complications: hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, DIC, compartment syndrome
Aggressive IV crystalloid (200-300 mL/hr) is cornerstone of treatment
Bicarbonate therapy controversial; may help if urine pH <6.5
content.statement: Rhabdomyolysis represents a medical emergency where rapid skeletal muscle breakdown releases potentially lethal amounts of intracellular contents. The kidney is particularly vulnerable to myoglobin-induced injury, but early aggressive fluid resuscitation can prevent AKI and dramatically improve outcomes.

explanation.intuition: Think of rhabdomyolysis as a 'flood' of muscle contents into the bloodstream. Myoglobin is normally contained within muscle cells, but when released in large quantities, it overwhelms the kidney's ability to handle it. Myoglobin precipitates in the tubules (especially in acidic, concentrated urine), directly damages tubular cells, and causes renal blood vessel constriction - a triple hit to the kidney.
explanation.key_insight: The key to preventing AKI is early and aggressive volume expansion. By diluting the myoglobin and increasing urine flow, you reduce tubular obstruction and wash out the toxic pigment before it can cause irreversible damage. Alkalinization of urine may help prevent myoglobin precipitation, though evidence is limited.
explanation.technical_details: Myoglobin (17 kDa) is freely filtered by the glomerulus. In the tubule, it is taken up by proximal tubular cells where the heme moiety generates reactive oxygen species through Fenton reactions. Myoglobin also causes cast formation (especially with Tamm-Horsfall protein in acidic urine) and vasoconstriction via nitric oxide scavenging. Volume depletion potentiates all these mechanisms by concentrating myoglobin and reducing tubular flow.

definitions_glossary.myoglobin: Oxygen-binding heme protein in skeletal and cardiac muscle; nephrotoxic when released in large amounts
definitions_glossary.creatine_kinase: CK - enzyme released from damaged muscle; >5× ULN indicates significant muscle injury
definitions_glossary.pigment_nephropathy: AKI caused by heme pigments (myoglobin or hemoglobin) damaging renal tubules
definitions_glossary.compartment_syndrome: Increased pressure within a fascial compartment compromising muscle perfusion; can cause and complicate rhabdomyolysis
definitions_glossary.crush_syndrome: Systemic effects of reperfusion after muscle compression; includes rhabdomyolysis and hyperkalemia
definitions_glossary.myoglobinuria: Myoglobin in urine causing dark brown color; positive dipstick blood without RBCs
definitions_glossary.hyperkalemia: Elevated serum potassium from muscle cell lysis; can cause cardiac arrhythmias
definitions_glossary.hypocalcemia: Low serum calcium from calcium precipitation in damaged muscle and phosphate binding
definitions_glossary.hypercalcemia_recovery: Calcium release during muscle healing can cause hypercalcemia in recovery phase
definitions_glossary.disseminated_intravascular_coagulation: DIC - coagulation activation from muscle breakdown products
definitions_glossary.Fenton_reaction: Iron-catalyzed generation of hydroxyl radicals; mechanism of myoglobin tubular toxicity
definitions_glossary.Tamm_Horsfall_protein: Glycoprotein secreted by tubules; coprecipitates with myoglobin forming casts
definitions_glossary.forced_alkaline_diuresis: Treatment strategy using IV fluids and bicarbonate to increase urine pH and flow
definitions_glossary.statin_myopathy: Muscle toxicity from statins; can cause rhabdomyolysis especially with drug interactions

pathophysiology.mechanism: Muscle cell injury releases myoglobin, CK, potassium, phosphate, and purines. Myoglobin causes AKI through: (1) tubular obstruction by myoglobin-Tamm-Horsfall protein casts, (2) direct proximal tubule toxicity via ROS generation, (3) renal vasoconstriction via NO scavenging.

non_traumatic: Drugs: statins (especially with fibrates/CYP3A4 inhibitors), alcohol, cocaine, amphetamines

signs: Signs of underlying cause (trauma, altered mental status)
Compartment syndrome signs (pain with passive stretch, tense compartment)

confirmatory: Elevated myoglobin (but clears faster than CK)
Positive urine blood on dipstick with few/no RBCs on microscopy
associated: Metabolic acidosis (high anion gap from organic acids)

urine_findings: Few or no RBCs on microscopy
imaging: Compartment pressure measurement if syndrome suspected

immediate: Aggressive IV crystalloid resuscitation (NS or LR) - goal 200-300 mL/hr urine output
Target fluid rate 1-2 L/hr initially, then titrate to urine output

electrolyte_management.hyperkalemia: Calcium gluconate (cardiac protection), insulin/glucose, kayexalate, dialysis if severe
electrolyte_management.hypocalcemia: Avoid calcium unless symptomatic (seizures, tetany, prolonged QTc) - calcium can deposit in muscles
electrolyte_management.hyperphosphatemia: Usually resolves with volume expansion; phosphate binders if severe

urine_alkalinization.rationale: Myoglobin is more nephrotoxic in acidic urine; alkalinization may prevent precipitation
urine_alkalinization.protocol: Add sodium bicarbonate to IV fluids to maintain urine pH >6.5
urine_alkalinization.evidence: Controversial; no RCTs showing benefit; consider if serum bicarb low and no contraindications
urine_alkalinization.contraindications: Hypocalcemia (alkalosis worsens), volume overload, severe alkalosis

dialysis_indications: Conventional dialysis does not clear myoglobin effectively

prognosis.good_outcomes: With early aggressive treatment, most patients recover renal function
prognosis.mortality: 5-10% overall; higher with delayed treatment, trauma, or multiorgan failure
prognosis.renal_recovery: Most recover within 2-4 weeks; some may have residual CKD

learning_objectives: Define rhabdomyolysis and explain the pathophysiology of myoglobinuric AKI
List common traumatic and non-traumatic causes of rhabdomyolysis
Interpret laboratory findings in rhabdomyolysis (CK, urine dipstick/microscopy discrepancy)
Describe the treatment approach including fluid resuscitation and electrolyte management
Recognize life-threatening complications (hyperkalemia, compartment syndrome, DIC)
Explain the rationale and controversy regarding urine alkalinization
clinical_pearls: Dipstick positive for blood but no RBCs on microscopy = myoglobinuria (or hemoglobinuria)
CK levels correlate with risk of AKI - watch closely when >15,000-20,000 U/L
Don't give IV calcium for asymptomatic hypocalcemia - it deposits in damaged muscles
Hyperkalemia from rhabdomyolysis can be severe and rapid - monitor closely
Hypercalcemia may occur during recovery as calcium mobilizes from damaged muscle
Volume is king - aggressive fluid resuscitation prevents most cases of AKI

common_question_stems: Patient found down with muscle weakness and dark urine
Post-marathon athlete with AKI and CK 45,000
Statin patient with muscle pain and elevated CK
Patient with crush injury and rising potassium
exam_tips: Rhabdomyolysis = very high CK + dark urine + dipstick positive but no RBCs
Hyperkalemia is the immediate life-threatening complication
Treatment = aggressive IV fluids (not dopamine, not mannitol as first-line)

teaching_cases.scenario: 28-year-old man found down in apartment after binge drinking. Presents confused with muscle weakness and cola-colored urine. Labs: CK 85,000, K 6.8, Cr 4.2, Ca 6.8.
teaching_cases.key_findings: Urine dipstick 3+ blood, microscopy shows 0-2 RBCs and pigmented casts
teaching_cases.diagnosis: Rhabdomyolysis with AKI from prolonged immobilization (alcohol intoxication)
teaching_cases.management: Aggressive IV NS, continuous cardiac monitoring, treat hyperkalemia, avoid calcium for hypocalcemia unless symptomatic

citations.authors: Bosch X, Poch E, Grau JM
citations.title: Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury

citations.authors: Chavez LO, Leon M, Einav S, Varon J
citations.title: Beyond muscle destruction: a systematic review of rhabdomyolysis for clinical practice

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on comprehensive review literature and clinical practice guidelines
